Edward, 48, lives with Benedicta, 38, and they have four children.  They live in their own house located in Sivia District.  Edward is a man who is dedicated to his business.  He works alongside his beloved wife selling charbroiled chickens in his own locale.  At the beginning, their sales weren’t very many until he started advertising his business with flyers.  This led to people being able to savor his delicious chickens that are seasoned with special condiments.  This was how Edward’s chicken shop forged ahead.  He acquired a large clientele and currently has a good-sized regular clientele.

Edward thanks MFP for facilitating a loan for him because with that help he was able to buy an electric oven.  Now, with this new loan he’s thinking about opening a new locale in Pichari District to start reaching his dream of owning a chain of chicken shops.

He is happy with the business because thanks to it he’s been improving economically.  This is his second MFP loan so he pledges to make his installment payments punctually.  Edward is happy with his communal bank because he’s learned to work better as a team.  He will use the requested 2500 to rent a new locale in Pichari District.

loans.use: to rent a locale to open another restaurant.

loans.name: Jargalsaikhan

texts.en: Jargalsaikhan is 51 years old.  He lives currently with his wife and all of his children have moved out their parents' home. He has been working as a freight transportation driver since 2002 and already has his permanent clients in Erdenet, the third largest city in Mongolia. His monthly earnings usually do not meet his family necessities, therefore Jargalsaikhan decided run another business such as a meat selling at a market near his home.  Meat sales volume is always intensified during the winter time in Mongolia and he wants to make his first dealing this December.  He needs to build his business working capital to buy red meat. The loan he is taking will be used to purchase a large amount of meat for his new bulk meat business.

loans.use: purchase meat

loans.name: El Progreso 1, 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Anita lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic, in a rural community. She is one of the borrowers from the group named El Progreso (The Progress) 1, 2 & 3, a group of Haitian citizens who have made their lives in the bateyes of the Dominican Republic.

Anita has two children who live with her and their father in a batey located in the north of San Pedro ("bateyes" are small rural communities built by sugar companies for their field workers). Despite her difficulties, Anita makes the most of her opportunities and she operates a little candy and snack stall where she sells candies such as gums and lollipops, and snack such as chips, cookies, and many other similar items. She operates her business during the day in front of the local school, and during the afternoon she moves her stall to her house. She visits other communities during the week, traveling to sell her products.

Anita is requesting a loan to purchase items to increase her inventory. Anita has had five previous loans and she has been able to bring changes to her family’s life, such as providing school supplies, shoes, clothing and tending to other needs.

loans.use: to buy candies, snacks, and other items.

loans.name: Fatuma's Group

texts.en:
Fatuma's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Fatuma is 22 years old and lives in the town of Lukaya in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has two children. For the past two years, Fatuma has been working hard to manage her small market, selling fruit.

To help expand her business, Fatuma has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruit for resale, and will help Fatuma to generate greater profits and take care of her children. Fatuma hopes that in the future she will be able to build her own house. 

Fatuma is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Fatuma's future prospects by helping her to her business has developed.

loans.use: to buy more fruits for resale

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Ny, 27, is married and resides with her husband, four children and a sister in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has been involved in an agricultural business for over five years. She has extensive experience and is successful in her career. She is involved in breeding pigs and producing palm sugar. Her husband helps her run the business. Additionally, he is a palm tree climber who climbs to get palm juice for his wife to produce palm sugar. 

In order to improve her palm sugar production to run smoothly, Ny is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a cart to carry firewood to cook palm juice to produce palm sugar and to purchase a long ladder for her husband to climb palm trees. In the future, she would like to expand her palm sugar production, build a new wooden house and send her children to a good school.

loans.use: to purchase a cart to carry firewood and to purchase a long ladder for her husband to climb palm trees.

loans.name: Francois

texts.en:
Francois is 56 years old. He is married with 9 children aged between 4 and 30 years, they all go to school. He is a farmer and he has been doing for the past 11 years. With the loan from kiva, he would like to pay the workers who harvested beans. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house and pay school fees for his children.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay the workers who harvested beans.

loans.name: Viola

texts.en: Hello! Meet Viola, a 39-year-old hardworking, honest, and dedicated farmer who lives in Chebara, a remote village in Kapsowar. She is happily married and has three children. Viola has been practicing mixed farming for the last five years and has gained much experience. To provide a decent and comfortable life for her children, she has been selling milk, eggs, and varieties of food crops from her farmland. Like many farmers from her region, Viola finds poultry farming very enjoyable and she stated that the most enjoyable part about poultry farming is “the increased profits I enjoy.” Her biggest business challenge is meeting demand, which is really high. Viola lacks funds to increase her poultry farm. Viola is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy poultry. Her loan will help her to sell eggs and poultry products to her neighbors and the local market. This will translate into increased profit and an improved income level. Being a visionary woman, Viola intends to accumulate more profits and expand her poultry business to other markets. She will use the profit from her loan to repay her loan, permanently change her living conditions, and secure the future of her three school-going children. Help her out!

loans.use: to buy poultry

loans.name: Karla Patricia Aguil

texts.en: My name is Karla Aguilar and I have a business selling clothing, shoes, and cosmetics door-to-door and by request for 5 years. I visit government offices, private companies, my largest buyers being teachers in urban and rural schools and employees of different institutions. I am requesting this loan in order to buy school clothes to increase my sales. With this money I can pay family and educational expenses.

loans.use: To buy shirts, blouses, shoes, socks, etc

loans.name: Sikavi

texts.en:
Mrs. Sikavi A. is married to a grower and is the mother of five (5) children. She did not have the chance for an education. She fights for the education of her children, so they won't have the same life as her. Honest and committed, she is one of the women of note in her village. Her main activity is the growing and sale of pineapples. This very profitable crop has always permitted Mrs. A. to provide for the needs of her children. A very scrappy woman, she has added the sale of cassava root flour to the sale of pineapples. Today, she wishes to increase the size of her pineapple field because the quality of the variety she grows means she is receiving orders from hotels in Lomé. She is asking for a loan of $700 dollars that she will use to pay workers and to acquire what's needed for the production of pineapples.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame A. Sikavi est une femme mariée à un cultivateur et mère de cinq (5) enfants. N’ayant pas eu la chance de s’instruire, elle se bat pour l’éducation de ses enfants pour que ces derniers ne connaissent pas le même sort qu’elle. Honnête et dévouée, elle est l’une des femmes de référence dans son village. Son activité principale est la culture et la vente d’ananas. Cette culture très rentable a toujours permis à Madame A. de pourvoir aux besoins de ses enfants. Femme très combative, elle joint à la culture d’ananas la vente de la farine de manioc (gari). Elle désire aujourd’hui agrandir son champ d’ananas car la qualité de la variété fait qu’elle reçoit des commandes depuis les hôtels de Lomé. Elle sollicite alors un crédit $700 qui va servir à payer la main d’œuvre et acquérir des intrants pour la production d’ananas.

loans.use: To pay workers and acquire what's needed to grow pineapples

loans.name: Seminariya

texts.en: Seminariya is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has four children. She started her business in 1994, and borrowed 7 Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $5200. Now she wants to borrow $2000.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Luís

texts.en:
Luis is a fruit and clothing vendor who sells his products from his tricycle cart. After working in local markets for several years, he decided there was too much competition and preferred to take his fruits directly to the homes of his clients. He has had success because it is more convenient for people to buy fruits when Luis passes by rather than going to the market. He also sells ties, belts, and other clothing accessories. He is seeking a second loan with Mifex in order to invest in new home products and appliances. He used his first loan to fix his cart and invest in more clothing.

Luis is 46 years old and has one son. He and his wife have been able to buy and fix up their home through hard work and savings. He tells us that his wife and son are his inspiration to go out and work hard from 5 in the morning into the evening.

loans.use: Invest in more clothing and also domestic appliances

loans.name: Idrise

texts.en: Idrise J. owns a small pharmacy in Kabala town.  He is thirty seven years old and married with two children.  He is assisted by his wife who is learning how to manage the business.   Mr. J. plans to increase his stock of basic medicines and would like a loan of $200.  As a family bread winner, and the elder son of his father he also takes care of his elderly parents.

loans.use: Purchase additional medicines to stock his pharmacy

loans.name: Cornelio Humberto

texts.en:
Cornelio Humberto T. has been selling fresh fish for 8 years. He fishes in the morning, and sells the fresh fish from his home in the afternoon. He sells fish to carnicerias, small markets.

He is requesting a loan of $175 to increase his sales and have a larger business. He is married, and has to support his wife and three children.

loans.use: Fish seller

loans.name: Julia

texts.en: Julia is 32 years old, married, and has two kids. She applied for this loan in order buy inventory for her small shop. She is very happy because this is the only opportunity for financial support that she can get to help out her small business. She says that in the past she didn’t make much profit, but things are going better now that she is able to expand her inventory. She thinks she is going to stay in the program for a long time and get more loans.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her small shop

loans.name: Mal

texts.en: Mrs. Mal H., 39, is a widow and works as a broker buying palm sugar and rice crops from growers and reselling them to the people in her community, making about $3/day in revenue. She has six children. Two of them assist in selling palm sugar and the other four are students. Mrs. Mal H. would like to increase her income generation to pay her children’s tuition fees and her family’s expenses. She plans to use the loan to expand her inventory by purchasing more palm sugar and rice crops to meet her clients’ demands. (Mrs. Mal H. is pictured with her son who is in school.)

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing more palm sugar and rice crops to meet her clients' needs.

loans.name: Tok

texts.en:
Mrs. Tok H., 38, is married with one school-age child and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She can usually earn about $2.50 each day in profit from selling her rice. Her husband is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver making typically around $4.60/day in revenue.

Mrs. Tok H. has lately requested a loan to expand her inventory by purchasing a large quantity of rice from the growers to meet her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of rice from the growers

loans.name: Kulwa's Baraka Group

texts.en:
Josophine is 32 years old, married, with two children, ages 10 and 7. Josophine owns a food vending store that she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $45 from her sales.

In the past, Josophine has taken out a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses in food and timber sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Señora Rosa is a member of the Progress Communal Bank. She has a restaurant on Raymondi Avenue in the district and province of Huaraz, department of Ancash.

With the loan of 2300 soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy 3 bags of rice, 5 bags of sugar, 100 liters of oil, 10 large packages of noodles and 5 bags of salt.

She is 65 years old and has 4 children. She has educated her children by herself because her husband passed away when her children were small. She has remarried and her new husband supports her in the business.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa pertenece al Banco Comunal El Progreso, tiene su restaurante en la Av. Raymondi del distrito y provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,300.00, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará, 3 sacos d arroz, 5 sacos de azúcar, 100 litros de aceite, 10 paquetes grandes de fideos, 5 sacos de sal.

Ella tiene 65 años de edad, tiene 4 hijos, ella ha educado a sus hijos sola porque su esposo falleció cuando sus hijos eran pequeños, se ha vuelto a casar y su esposo le apoya en el negocio.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, noodles and salt for her restaurant.

loans.name: Verita Luz

texts.es:
Verita belongs to the Communal Bank “The Shipibas”, located in the Jr. Mayan of Britto Cdra 1, of the District of Calleria of the Department of Ucayali. She is 55 years old and is a mother of 7 children. Her husband is a merchant, and upon seeing that his money could not support their daily life she decided to take out a loan. She received a loan of 300 PEN and decided to use it to purchase and sell faro, tapioca and beans.

Currently, she sells her products in Bellavista market, and begins selling very early each day. At night she rests to have the energy to be able to continue business the next day.

With this loan of 1,000 PEN (approximately $375), which will be repaid in four months, she will buy 20 kg of tapioca and 20 kg of beans. Verita says that the branches of Manuela Ramos provides great aupport and allows her the opportunity to work and to be able to support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sedloff, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Verita pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Shipibas, ubicado en el Jr. Maya de Britto Cdra 1, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años es madre de 7 hijos, su esposo es comerciante, al ver que no le alcanzaba el dinero para su economía diaria decide sacar un préstamo, es así que Verita con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la compra y venta de fariña, tapioca y menestras.

En la actualidad vende sus productos en el mercado de bellavista, se va muy temprano para empezar su venta del día, y en las noches descansa para tener energías para el día siguiente siempre dándole para adelante.

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000 el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 20 Kg. de fariña, 20 Kg. de tapioca, 20 Kg. de fréjol.

Verita dice que trabajar con Manuela Ramos es un gran apoyo por que le permite trabajar y puede apoyar en la economía de su hogar.

La señora Verita pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Shipibas, ubicado en el Jr. Maya de Britto Cdra 1, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años es madre de 7 hijos, su esposo es comerciante, al ver que no le alcanzaba el dinero para su economía diaria decide sacar un préstamo, es así que Verita con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la compra y venta de fariña, tapioca y menestras. En la actualidad vende sus productos en el mercado de bellavista, se va muy temprano para empezar su venta del día, y en las noches descansa para tener energías para el día siguiente siempre dándole para adelante. Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000 el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 20 Kg. de fariña, 20 Kg. de tapioca, 20 Kg. de fréjol. Verita dice que trabajar con Manuela Ramos es un gran apoyo por que le permite trabajar y puede apoyar en la economía de su hogar.

loans.use: With the loan, she will buy more products to sell

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Nguyễn Thị Hồng is 42 years old. She participates in TYM fund since 2007. Her 2 children are grown up. She has a small store selling basic goods. Her business model is to make small profit on each item to keep the price down but to sell a lot of merchandise. Her store is always busy. Her husband is very supportive of her and their 2 children do help her out. Since she just started this business, her inventory is low. This is why she is applying for a loan of 375 USD to buy more merchandise for her store. Her monthly income is around 170 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng, 42 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2007. 2 người con của chị đều đã qua tuổi đi học. Công việc chính của chị là bán hàng tạp hóa. Bán được nhiều hàng nhưng ăn lãi ít đó là phương châm của chị Hồng. Vì vậy dù mới mở cửa hàng nhưng nhà chị lúc nào cũng đông khách. Chồng chị luôn giúp chị tích cực trong việc đồng áng, hai con cũng đi làm để hỗ trợ gia đinh. Mới bắt đầu nên số lượng hàng hóa bày bán cũng chưa nhiều. Vì vậy chị Hồng xin vay mức 375USD mua thêm nhiều hàng về bán phục vụ nhiều hơn cho bà con nhân dân và nâng cao mức thu nhập trong gia đình. Thu nhập bình quân của chị hiện nay khoảng 170USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang S. is 31 years old, married and lives in Kampong Cham province with her husband and their three young children. Each day, she goes to the market and sells Khmer noodles, making about $3.30. Her husband works in recycling and makes around $10 a day, but his business has room for expansion. Seang S. has applied to CREDIT for a loan of $700 to buy more items to resell at the local recycling plant. She sees this loan as a good investment in her husband’s business, and a way to increase her family’s income. She is very confident that the business venture will succeed and allow her family to raise its standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more materials to resell at a local recycling plant.

loans.name: Neves Changoma

texts.pt:
Neves Changoma N. is 47 years old. He's from Tete in the centre of Mozambique and is the father of 3 children. He lives with his wife, their 3 children and 4 step-children. They are officially married.

Neves was in school until 9th grade and stopped as he had to attend obligatory military service. In 1969 he had signed up as a member of FRELIMO (Mozambican Liberation Front) and in 1983 entered obligatory military service and went to train in an official capacity in Umbelezi, where he worked until his retirement.

Neves is retired with a monthly pension of 4997,00 MZN (around $200). This is his third loan and they were all used to buy construction materials for his house. He dreams of seeing his house finished and fully furnished and as such he intends to pay the loan in full before it is due so that he can request another loan.

Translated from Portuguese by Inês Teles, Kiva volunteer.

Neves Changoma N. tem 47 anos de idade é natural de Tete ao centro de Moçambique e pai de 3 filhos. Vivem com esposa, seus 3 filhos e 4 enteados. Casado maritalmente. Neves estudou até 9ªclasse e parou por incorporar se ao serviços militar obrigatório. Em 1969 tinha se inscrito como membro do partido frelimo e em 1983 foi ingressou nos serviço militar obrigatório e foi treinar em arte oficiais em Umbelezi onde trabalhou até a sua reforma. Neves é reformado com uma pensão mensal de 4997,00mt. Este é o terceiro empréstimo e todos foram usados na compra de material para construção da sua casa. Tem como sonho ver a sua casa concluida e mobilada assim pretende pagar antes do tempo para solicitar outro crédito.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to finish building his house

loans.name: Benkadi (L'entente Est Bonne) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de femmes mariées vivant en générale dans des foyers polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 1 enfant et résidant dans le quartier Ouayerma II de la ville de  Sikasso (troisième région économique du Mali)
Ces femmes exercent le commerce de pagnes wax (tissus très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest), de friperies, de savons, de patates douces, de pommes de terre, d’ignames, des fruits et légumes et divers autres articles.
Unies par des liens de parenté et d’alliance, les femmes du groupe  décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe et tous les précedents ont été remboursés correctement. Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 2 ballots de friperie, 5 pièces de pagnes wax, 30kg de tissus coupons, 6 cartons de savons, 10  chargements de bois de chauffe et quelques paniers de fruits et légumes.
 Elles s’approvisionnent généralement au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso (quelques fois à Bamako et au Burkina Faso ) auprès des grossistes attitrés et dans les localités environantes auprès de paysans producteurs de fruits et légumes. Ensuite elles viennent  revendre ces articles dans les quartiers de façon ambulante, dans les marchés avec une place fixe sous des hangars. Les ventes sont en majorité au comptant et quelques fois à crédit. La clientèle est composée essentiellement  des femmes .
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 22.500FCFA, lequel sera utilisé pour payer les intêrets du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of married women, 32 years old with one child on average, and generally living in polygamous households in the neighborhood of Ouayerma II in the city of Sikasso (third largest economic region in Mali). These women work in the sale of “Wax pagnes” (a very popular fabric in West Africa), second-hand clothing, soaps, sweet potatoes, potatoes, yams, fruits and vegetables and other items. United through relatives and friends, the women of the group decided to incorporate a loan program through the micro finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with which they are requesting their fourth group loan, all the previous loans having been correctly repaid. With this loan they plan to buy 2 bundles of second-hand clothes, 5 pieces of “wax pagnes,” 30kg of scrap fabrics, 6 boxes of soaps, 10 loads of firewood and some baskets of fruits and vegetables. In general they get their supplies at the large city market in Sikasso (sometimes in Bamako or Burkina Faso) at official wholesalers and in surrounding areas at local fruit and vegetable producers. Then they travel and sell these items in neighborhood markets with set booths. The sales are mostly paid cash down and sometimes on credit. The clientele is made up primarily of women. They hope to earn a monthly profit of 22,500 F CFA, which they will use to pay loan interest and invest the remainder in business.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Kin

texts.en: Kin T. is 53 years old and has worked raising animals on her plot of land since 1983. On average, she makes US$2 each day. Her husband is an old farmer growing cucumbers and is able to make US$2 each day as well. This couple together has one child, who works at a garment factory. Farming is making less profit to support the family, so Kin has decided to take out a loan of US$1000 to build a big stand selling rice and food in front of a garment factory. This will allow her family to earn much more than farming and raising animals.

loans.use: To build a big stand selling rice and food in front of a garment factory.

loans.name: Mwanabaraka's Group

texts.en:
Mwanabaraka has had a shop selling clothing and juices in Zanzibar since 2006. In order to get inventory for her shop, she buys second-hand clothing sent from other countries (like the United States) in bulk and sells it to the local people. She also buys locally-produced juices like mango and passion fruit juice and sells them to the students in her neighborhood. She works every day from 8:30 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of approximately $130.

Mwanabaraka is 33 years old, married, and has two children ages 8 and 15. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to buy more inventory and increase her sales and profit. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mashavu, who also has a shop in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her small shop.

loans.name: Salome

texts.es: Salome tiene 38 años, es madre de 3 hijos, vive junto a su esposo, quien le brinda su apoyo incondicional. Su actividad diaria es la venta de comida, y lo hace en la hora del desayuno y el almuerzo, ella vende desde hace 8 años. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es dar una buena atención a sus clientes y sobre todo que estos degusten de su buena sazón. Le es muy rentable, ya que es muy conocida por su zona y lo que es más, se encuentra en un lugar muy transitable y concurrente. Le va bien en su negocio de la venta de comida y esta muy satisfecha. Este es el primer préstamo con MFP. El dinero que solicita será para ampliar su negocio, ambientarlo  de una manera adecuada, para dar una mejor vista y mejor atención a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Salome is 38 years old, has 3 children and lives with her husband to whom she offers unconditional support. Her business activity is prepared food that is sold for breakfast and lunch. She has been doing this for 8 years. It is gratifying to her to provide excellent service to her customers so that they can enjoy her exquisite flavors. She has done well because she is a well-known person around her neighborhood, and the restaurant is located at a very busy spot in the city. Sales have been solid and she is very satisfied with the results. This will be the first loan from MFP. She wants to expand and better equip the business: a more functional restaurant will help her provide even better services to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand and improve her business

loans.name: Omina

texts.en: J. Omina  is 44 years old. She is married and has 4 children. Mrs. J. has been an active client of our program since 2004. She is a reliable and executive client. She trades eggs in the central bazaar and is a hardworking woman. Mrs. J. has been selling eggs for 5 years and she is thankful for Kiva's support.

loans.use: support her egg selling business

loans.name: Eulogia

texts.en:
Eulogia is a member of the Señor D. los Milagros (Our Father of Miracles) Village Bank. Eulogia is 49 years old and married with eight children. Eulogia travels to different regional fairs, where she sells vegetables, grains, and flour. She buys other grains at the markets, which she then grinds into flour and resells in the Ayacuchan jungle, where she goes to buy her fruit.  Eulogia needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy grains. Eulogia dreams of building her own home, of improving her business, and that her children will graduate from college with professional degrees. 

 Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Eulogia es socia del Banco Comunal Señor D. los Milagros. 
Eulogia es casada, tiene 49 años y 8 hijos, Eulogia viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región en donD. vendía verduras, cereales, harinas y D. las ferias compra cereales que luego procesa en harina y lo venD. en la selva ayacuchana D. donD. trae frutas. 
Eulogia necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. cereales. 
Eulogia sueña con construir su casa, mejorar su negocio y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy grains to make flour

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac A. sells plank (lumber) at the Songo plank market, Ibadan, Nigeria. He has been in this business for a long time. He hopes to expand this business and is requesting a loan amount of $425 (N60,000) to purchase more plank to sell. He is 46-years-old and is married with three children. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more plank to sell

loans.name: M'mola Group

texts.en:
Mwaka owns a small charcoal store and also sells coconuts in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She has been in business for 10 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. She works 14 hours a day and she is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and coconuts for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.  

Mwaka is 45 years old, widowed, and has eight children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Fatma, Rehema M. and Rehema R.. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and coconuts for her business.

loans.name: Dulmaa

texts.en: Dulmaa S. is a widowed mother of three children. She lives with her eldest son in Uvurhangay, one of Mongolia's southern provinces. Her two youngest sons are college students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. Together with her eldest son, Tumurbaatar, she runs a raw hide business that uses yak, sheep and goat skins. Her son buys raw hides from countryside herders and she then sells them to buyers in the center of the province. Sometimes Tumurbaatar goes to Ulaanbaatar to sell raw hides for a higher price. Dulmaa also runs a sewing business from her home, making traditional coats called "deels." During April, students who will graduate in May order traditional dresses for their graduation celebration. To prepare for the spike in demand Dulmaa prepares many different colors of silk. Dulmaa has a wonderful work ethic and a positive attitude. She will use the loan she receives to invest in her business by increasing her inventory of silk and raw hides.

loans.use: To buy silk and raw hides

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia sells and rents VCDs to her customers. She started this business in 2001. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell and rent to her customers. She hopes to expand this business. She is 30 years old and married with 3 childern. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to rent and sell

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
X. Nguyễn, 54, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has three adult children. To make a living, X. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. X. has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, X. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. X. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. That loan was used to expand the business. X. is requesting a new loan of 15000000 VND which will be used to purchase breeding livestock.

The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by X. from TYM Fund. X. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy breeding livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more shoes

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria D. 50 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora y solidaria con sus socias, vive en su propia casa y lo que más desea es tener una buena vida. Acompañada D. su inseparable máquina D. tejer, realiza sus hermosos tejidos artesanales, venD. en un puesto ubicado en la Explanada Laguna Temporal (lugar donD. se realizan ferias en Juliaca). A Maria le gusta mucho tejer, es por eso que siempre hace modelos novedosos, aunque no todo lo que teje es fácil, ya que es complicado tejer los chullos (prenda para la cabeza), que son los que más se venden a los turistas. Para el futuro tiene pensado poner una tienda donD. pueda vender ella misma sus tejidos. El deseo D. Maria, es progresar en la vida y tener un soporte económico con el cual pueda afrontar los difíciles años D. vejez. Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP, está dispuesta a pagar sin demora sus cuotas, para no perjudicarse y no meter en problemas a su banco comunal. Con los mil doscientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará más lana para producir más tejidos artesanales.
texts.en:
Maria, 50, is a very hard working woman who is supportive of her colleagues. She lives in her own house, and what she wants most of all is to have a good life. Accompanied by her inseparable weaving machine, she makes beautiful woven crafts. She sells from a stand located in Explanada Laguna Temporal (where they have the fairs in Juliaca). Maria really likes to weave. That is why she always makes new styles, even though everything she weaves is not easy. It is complicated to weave the “chullos” (hats), which they sell the most of to the tourists. In the future she plans to set up a store where she can sell what she weaves. Maria’s wish is to progress in life and to have the economic support to face the difficult years of old age. This is her second loan with MFP. She is ready to make her payments on time in order to not be detrimental to or cause problems for her community bank. With the 1,200 PEN she will buy more wool to produce more woven crafts.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wool for the crafts she weaves

loans.name: Sherzot

texts.en: For the past ten years, M. Sherzot has put much effort into his agricultural activities. He learned this humble work from his father. His father taught him everything about farming so that, when he had his own family, he could support his wife as well as his children. Now, Sherzot is busy preparing his farm for their next planting. Sherzot, the father of two small children, says his wish is that he will again have an abundant harvest. He would like to ask for a loan of 1,000 Somoni that will be used for purchasing fertilizers, herbicides and ammonium sulfate. Sherzot is sure that the loan will help him improve his harvest and he thanks everyone who supports him with this loan. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, herbicides and ammonium sulfate

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace K. is 24 years old. She is married and has given birth to one child, a son who is currently in the primary school. She lives with her child and husband in a rented apartment in Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Her husband is a commercial driver. Grace is a baker. She bakes bread in her community and supplies to retailers and beverage sellers.  She also hawks to sell as well. She buys bags of flour and other ingredients from Kumasi. Grace has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk. She desires to expand her business and give her son a good education.

loans.use: To buy flour in bulk

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
K. Rano is an enterprising business owner from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She has an attractively arranged women’s clothing store, situated in the local market, “Ganjina”. Rano has been in business for 5 years. She is married and has 3 children, a son and two daughters. Her son is currently finishing college. Rano has requested a loan of $800 USD to purchase a selection of women’s clothing. She hopes to continue to make a good profit and to earn additional income for her family. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase inventory of women's clothing.

loans.name: Panfilo

texts.es: El señor Panfilo D.
texts.en: Panfilo D.

loans.use: Buy material for his carpentry shop

loans.name: Leopoldo Roberto

texts.es:
El señor Leopoldo Chavarría D.  es una persona que siempre a buscado el bienestar de su familia, con los años fue juntando dinero para comprar un terreno ahora el esta construyendo y le falta el techo de su vivienda. El vive en la casa de su mama mientra termina la construcción, pero ya la familia va creciendo y necesita su espacio y privacidad como pareja.
Leopoldo tiene tres hijos a quienes piensa dejarles un buen patrimonio y buen hogar para cuando ellos crezcan es por ello que pide un prestímano para comprar material y pagar mano para terminar la construcción.
La señora y el trabajan en maquiladora para el sostén de ellos mismos con estos ingresos ellos pagarían el préstamo otorgado.
texts.en:
Leopoldo Chavarría D. is a person who is always looking out for his family's well-being. Over the years he was raising money to buy land, and he is now building a home on it but it's missing a roof. He is living in his mother's home while the construction is being completed, but his family continues to grow and he needs space and privacy with his wife. Leopoldo has three children whom has wants to leave with a good patrimony and a good home when they grow up, and it's for this reason he is requesting a loan to purchase material and pay for the construction to be completed. He and his wife work at a factory to provide for themselves, and with this income they will repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Put a roof on his home

loans.name: Akouwa

texts.fr: Cette dame vend en gros une boisson alcoolisée très appréciée de la population dénommée « sodabi ». Elle a débuté son activité en 2008 dans le quartier de Bè-Kpota à Lomé ; actuellement elle dispose d’un nombre important de clients, et approvisionne même les bars et restaurants de la place. Elle vend aussi des bidons de sodabi à des vendeuses de détail de cette boisson populaire. Elle doit renouveler en ce moment son stock ; pour cela elle voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour commander 50 bidons de « sodabi » ; le reste du prêt lui servira à couvrir ses frais de transport vers le Bénin, le pays voisin où elle s’approvisionne. Cette femme est mariée et est mère d’un enfant. Elle est fière de ce commerce qui lui réussit en ce moment.
texts.en:
This lady is a wholesale seller of an alcoholic drink called "sodabi" that is much appreciated by the population.  She started her business in 2008 in the Bè-Kpota district in Lomé; currently, she has a significant number of customers and even supplies local bars and restaurants.  She also sells drums of sodabi to retailers of this popular drink.  She must renew her stock now;  to do so, she would like to obtain a WAGES loan to order 50 drums of sodabi;  the rest of the loan will be used to cover the costs of transport to Benin, the neighboring country where she stocks up.  This is a married woman who is the mother of one child.  She is proud of this business, which is successful for her right now.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers of alcoholic drinks

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.en:
Rachelle R. is from the village of Puli, Carmen, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 39 years old. Rachelle is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Rachelle owns and operates a 'sari-sari' (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rachelle has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rachelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rachelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rachelle is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rachelle from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Getruda

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27  years old Getruda  M.  from Mbarali  She is married  with one   child, of 5 yrs old  Getruda has been running a clothes  business since 2006. Client’s business is purchasing and selling clothes. She works at the business for 9-12  hours per day, 6 days per week Getruda currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase clothes in bulk for her business . In the future, she plans to open the same business at new location . Getruda thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk for her business

loans.name: Phalla's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Phalla T. is a group leader of four members who all lives in Popeal Khaer village in Kandal province. She is a vegetable seller in the local market. Since business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more vegetables to resell. She hopes to increase income and improve the family living with this loan. Mrs. Phalla T. is a 42 year old widow with four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Mrs. Ta C. did not come to take a loan but her husband is presented in the picture instead.

loans.use: By purchasing more vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes is 59 years old, and has four children with her husband Roman, who is a farmer. Three of her children are already married. They live in the village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela.

Mercedes is in the hog-raising business. In a desire to improve her business, she is now applying for a PHP15,000 loan from KIVA lenders. She will use the capital to purchase feed and additional piglets, which she will raise to increase her income.  She is hoping that her request will be granted by KIVA lenders so she can provide for her family and make her business profitable.

loans.use: to purchase feed and additional piglets

loans.name: Hermesia

texts.en:
Hermesia N. is from the village of Taguima in Tdela, Misamis Occidental. She is 63 years old. Hermesia is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Hermesia sells clothing and shoes in the local community. Hermesia has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Hermesia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hermesia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC that she used to purchase additional products to sell. Hermesia is requesting a new loan of 16000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Hermesia's 9th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya comprend six femmes, deux veuves et quatre  mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, elles ont  en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et habitent le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative  de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, professionnel, d’amitié et font le commerce d’articles  divers, la teinture et la restauration.
Dans le souci rentabiliser et de diversifier leurs activités elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 5ème prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre précédents. 
Ce  prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe, 10 sacs de riz et 35 tenues vestimentaires pour enfants. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en riz habituellement  au marché Château de Ségou, en  bois de chauffe auprès des exploitants  de Diakoro et de Kolonkolo et les habits  pour enfants au marché château. Les ingrédients pour la restauration le  riz, le haricot, les spaghettis, le poisson, la viande etc sont achetés au grand marché de Ségou. 
Elles effectuent leur vente en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 43.250FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, à la satisfaction des petits besoins familiaux et à la participation aux évènements sociaux (baptêmes, mariages, funérailles). 
Leur ambition est d’avoir  une concession à usage d’habitation propre à leurs enfants et à elles car le commun n’est pas une propriété en soi.
texts.en:
The Danaya group includes six women, two widowed and four are married in big traditional families. They are on average 37 years old with 4 kids and live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood in the town on Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali.) They know each other from around the neighborhood, through professional ties and friendship. They do business in a varied goods as well as cloth dyeing and food preparation. It's in the wish of making more profitable and diversifying their activities that they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. They are on their 5th group loan after correctly repaying the 4 proceeding ones.

This loan would be used to buy 20 cart loads of firewood, 10 bags of rice and 35 children's outfits. They usually stock up on rice at market in Château de Ségou, on wood from farmers in Diakoro and Kolonkolo and on kids clothing at Château market. The ingredients for the food preparations the rice, the beans, the noodles, the fish and meat are bought at the large market of Ségou.

They carry out their retail sales in cash and credit to both men and women. The plan to average a monthly income of 43.250FCFA which would be used to repay the loan, to see to the small needs of the families and be used to participate in social events (baptisms, marriages and funerals.) Their dream is to have claim to decent housing for them and their kids because the joint housing is not solely owned by them.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of varried goods

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is thirty years old. She is widowed and has three children to care for, all of whom are schooling. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Grace works hard to be able to provide for the family. She trades in utensils. Grace buys from Accra and sells them in her community. She also treks to sell in nearby towns. She has been in business for three years and yearns to increase her stock. It is her desire to give all her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy utensils.

loans.name: Alejandro Jose

texts.es:
El Señor Alejandro José  Sánchez O., Labora como encargado de limpieza (Higienista) en el Mercado Oriental de Managua, el tiene cuatro  hijos a su cargo, tres de ellos se encuentran en edad escolar, esta Casado, ha trabajado diez créditos con CEPRODEL durante Siete años, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido 10 créditos en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias al financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL,  el es un cliente excelente.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción, por lo que comprara dos ventanas de madera para su casa de habitación ya que las que tenía se encontraban deterioradas.
 Todo esto con el objetivo de Brindarles mayor seguridad y  una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.
Alejandro dijo que los préstamos otorgados han sido para el mejoramiento de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Sr. Alejandro José Sánchez O. is the head of sanitation at the Eastern Market in Managua. He is married and has four dependent children in school. Alejandro has worked with CEPRODEL for seven years. He used the ten loans he received to make improvements to his home. Alejandro is an excellent client.

The loan he is requesting will be used to purchase construction materials. Two of the wooden window frames on his house were damaged and need to be replaced. His main objective is to provide greater security and better living conditions for his children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is 62 years old and married, with seven adult children. She has a farm in the Murang'a area of the Central Province of Kenya and she's been farming for over twenty years. She's a pig farmer but also earns some income from mixed farming. She says that the major challenges to her business are a lack of funds to buy animal feed and improve her pig sty.

She requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 48,920. She'll use 45,000 to buy pigs and the remaining 3,920 to subscribe to the medical aid that Juhudi offers its clients.

In the future, Annah hopes to improve and expand her pig sty so that it can hold more than fifty pigs. Through more investment in her pig farm, she believes she'll be able to eventually improve her homestead with a better house. She hopes that she can continue to be a Juhudi client, since she requires more assets to achieve her goal.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is a for-profit social enterprise focused on the economic development of Kenya. It has a unique approach to financing agribusiness value chains, from production of raw products to processing and delivery of goods: by providing asset financing and technical assistance funding to smallholder farmers and rural enterprises. This approach to poverty alleviation supports sustainable wealth creation in rural communities, establishes local engines of income generation, and generates employment, economic growth and dynamism as well as demand for inputs.

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise

loans.name: Chheob

texts.en:
Mrs. Chheob P. is 36 years old and she lives in Moeang Prachen village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.3-hectare (3.25-acre) field on which she grows crops. She also raises pigs and is able to earn a small income to support her living.

Mrs. Chheob P. is now requesting loan of 1,000,000 Riel from AMK to enlarge her business and purchase fertilizer to grow more crops. She hopes to earn additional revenue so she can improve the living conditions of her family.

Mrs. Chheob P. is a widow with five children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory while the other four are students in the local school and also help their mother with her work.

loans.use: To enlarge her pig-raising business and purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Erkebubu's Group

texts.en:
Mutual assistance has been one of the most effective ways to struggle against poverty all over the world. Probably the main problem that causes most of the uprisings and revolts in Third World countries is the expanding rupture between the rich and the poor. So, what the microfinance organizations have been doing has greatly relieved the situation, as it has given tens of millions of people an opportunity to start their business and improve their standard of living. An amount of money that may seem nothing to a rich businessman, who spends this sum every day having lunch in a restaurant, is to another person vital initial capital, with which he or she could start a new life. And that’s what makes this life interesting!

Erkebubu is the leader of this loan group. She is 49 and the mother of two children. She is raising her children on her own as she has been divorced for the last few years. To provide for her little family, Erkebubu produces national milk soft drinks – “bozo” and “maksym” (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyrgyz_cuisine for more information). This seemingly small business has allowed her to make repairs in her apartment. Now her monthly income has reached $420. Erkebubu needs a loan to increase the amount of drinks she sells. She hopes to save money to buy strawberry seedlings.

Erkebubu’s partners are:
Gulmira, 38, is divorced. She has two children and needs a loan for personal use. She is planning to purchase furniture.
Erkingul, 34, is a mother of two children. Her husband provides welding services. Erkingul is engaged in network marketing and sells perfumes, cosmetics and detergents. She is requesting a loan to purchase goods and also buy a TV set with plasma screen.
Chinara is the youngest member of this group at 25 years old. She works as a saleswoman selling bed clothing and dishes. She decided to apply for a loan after her sister advised her to purchase more goods to attract more customers. Chinara’s current monthly income is $185.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To increase the amount of milk soft drinks she sells

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en: Luzminda M. is from the village of Cantaan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Luzminda is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Luzminda owns and operates a service-based business. Her main source of income from the business comes from providing transport services using her own motorcycle. For the whole day, she lets this motorcycle be rented by any habal-habal driver for 150-200 pesos per day. Luzminda has been engaged in her business for over seven years. In 2009, Luzminda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos from HSPFI. Luzminda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide better service. This will be the third loan taken out by Luzminda from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide better service

loans.name: Clementina

texts.en:
Clementina P. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.

Clementina is 37 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.


About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Karidia

texts.fr:
Née le 10 Août 1975 à Sikasso, Karidia B. est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Wayerma II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Karidia B. est une aide soignante de formation qui n’a jamais exercé cette profession. Elle s’est plutôt initiée et s’installée dans les activités d’achat et de vente d’articles divers de boutique dont elle dispose une  devant le domicile conjugal où elle mène cette activité d’achat et vente  d’articles divers tels, les eaux minérales,  des œufs, les Cigarettes,  les bonbons, allumettes, Chewing-gum, lait en poudre, Thé, sucre, etc il y a environ 4 ans. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association BENKADI de Wayerma I), elle est à son troisième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 4 cartouches de Cigarettes différentes,10 paquets de Chewing-gum, 2 cartons de lait en poudre (en sachets), 10 gros paquets du thé, 1 sacs du sucre, 6 alvéoles d'œuf   , 10 paquets de bonbon, 4 cartons de l’eau DIAGO, 20 paquets d’allumette, etc. 
Elle achète ses marchandises chez les commerçants grossistes de place avant de les revendre en détail au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée des voisins et surtout des jeunes..
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born 10 August 1975 in Sikasso, Karidia B. is married and mother of three children. She lives with her husband and their children in Wayerma II, one of several populous neighborhoods in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mrs. Karidia B. is a trained caregiver who has never practiced as such. Four years ago she began trading various items she sells in a store located in the front of her home: mineral water, eggs, cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing-gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, etc. She is quite in demand by her customers for the quality of her products. To satisfy an increasing number of customers, she decided three years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. After four group loans in a neighbourhood women’s association (the Benkadi Association of Wayerma I), she is now requesting a third individual loan. All preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed. With this loan she will buy: four cartons of various cigarettes, 10 packages of chewing-gum, two cartons of powdered milk (in bags), 10 large packages of tea, one bag of sugar, 10 packages of sweets, four cartons of Diago mineral water, 20 matchboxes, etc. She gets her supplies from local wholesalers before selling them retail, for cash or credit, to customers from the area and particularly the young. She hopes to reach monthly earnings of 200,000 FCFA which will be used to increase her working capital, share family expenses, reimburse her loan and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various general store products

loans.name: Mirembe Katenga, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Hardworking M. Lawrence started up his motorcycle transport business four years ago. As motorcycles are a very common means of conveyance in timely situations like traffic jams and bad road systems in Uganda, he has made good profit out of it, earning 200,000 Ugandan shillings.

Lawrence’s main setback is that he needs to expand the business through buying additional motorcycles to allocate them in different stages so as to increase his revenue. With this loan he hopes to achieve that and thus will be able to take care of his family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Tomás

texts.es:
El Sr. Tomás B. es de la compañía Simbrón,  cuenta con casa propia, se dedica a la compra – venta de animales vacunos, esta actividad económica lo realiza hace varios años. 

Cuenta con mucha experiencia en la actividad que realiza, lo que le permite tener un buen manejo del negocio, mencionando que cuenta con buena clientela. 
Su metodología consiste en que el compra los animales y con un tratamiento en cuanto a la alimentación y sanitación rápidamente puden ser vendidos con mejor precio.

Solicita el préstamo para la compra de animales vacunos.
texts.en:
Mr. Tomás B. is with the company, "Simbrón". He has his own house and for a living he has been buying and selling cattle for several years.

His vast experience allows him to manage his business well, and he can also count on good customers.

His method is to buy the animals and with a treatment as to feeding and sanitation be able to sell them fast at a more profitable price.

The loan will be spent on buying cattle.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cattle

loans.name: Maria Carmen

texts.es:
La Sra. María Vanegas es una socia activa del banco comunal Chochapamba, hace 2 años, en el cual ha logrado una muy buena amistad con todas sus amigas y compañeras. Vive en la comunidad de San Miguel que pertenece a la parroquia del Valle, esta parroquia es conocida por su productividad agrícola, la misma que abastece a su población, su gente también se dedica a la ganadería, muchos salen a la ciudad en busca de un mejor trabajo, como también una gran parte de la población joven a migrado a otras partes del mundo, para brindarles un mejor futuro a sus familias.

Nuestra socia se dedica a los quehaceres de su casa y al mismo tiempo aprovecha para criar animales como: pollos, cuyes, los mismos que los vende en su propia comunidad.

Doña María tiene 49 años de edad, es casada y en su unión conyugal ha concebido 3 hijos de los cuales dos son casados y ya viven de manera independiente, su último hijo es soltero, se dedica a trabajar y ayuda en la economía del hogar, su esposo es albañil actividad que le ha beneficiado para salir adelante con su familia, gracias al trabajo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia. El nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la comprar de pollos para seguir creciendo en este negocio y salir adelante.
texts.en:
María has been an active member of the Chochapamba communal bank for the past 2 years, in which she has formed good relationships with all of her friends and co-members. She lives in the community of San Miguel, which belongs to the parish of Valle. This parish is known for its agricultural productivity, which supplies its population. Its people are also involved in cattle farming. Many leave for the city in search of a better job, and a large portion of the young generation has migrated to other parts of the world to provide a better future for their families.

María does the household chores in her house and at the same time takes of advantage of the time to raise animals such as chickens and guinea pigs, which she sells in her community.

María is 49 years old, married, and in her marriage has conceived 3 children, two of which are married and now live independently and their youngest son is single. María works and helps the household economy. Her husband is a builder, a job which has helped him to get ahead with his family. Thanks to her husband’s work, they have been able to build their own house. She is going to invest the new loan in the purchase of chickens to continue growing her business and to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase chickens

loans.name: Murod

texts.en:
M. Murod is 47 years old. He is married and has 5 children. Murod is very diligent and hard-working young man. With his own car, he is providing  taxi services. For the last 10 years the current business has been the main income for the family, allowing Murod to improve the living conditions of his large family. As with any business, Murod's business also requires some investment from time to time. Thus, now his car needs some fixing. For this purpose Murod requests 4700 Somoni. Murod promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all those supporting him.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Thorough fixing of the vehicle used for providing taxi services.

loans.name: Mwanamgeni

texts.en: Mwanamgeni is married with five children. Four of the children attend school and one is too young for school. She has been selling charcoal for the past year. She sells from home to her neighboring community. With the Kshs 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase fruits and two sacks of charcoal. Her other source of income is selling soft drinks. Her husband also contributes to her income. The main challenge she faces is seasonality, especially during rainy seasons. She owns a house with electricity and piped water. Mwanamgeni hopes that someday she can open a charcoal stall and become a potential supplier. She decided to work with Yehu because of its good reputation. She cites electricity and school fees as her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To purchase fruit and charcoal.
